abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, this project is rated
            satisfactory. The early stages of the project were difficult
            for both sides, but the final outcome is conspicuously
            successful in regard to policy reform and transition to a
            market economy. World Bank staff performed appropriately
            throughout; and at the broad level of restructuring and
            privatization of urban transport, the government of
            Kazakhstan's performance has been highly satisfactory.
            These lessons can be learned from the project: Contrary to
            widely-held perceptions in the region, it is possible to
            operate an effective urban public transport system in a
            transition economy without subsidy. Privatization and the
            elimination of uncompensated free-travel privileges require
            firm commitment at the highest levels of government to
            development in the private sector and hard budget
            constraints in the public sector. Centralized purchase of
            buses through the public sector is sub-optimal: ideally
            operators should make their own purchase decisions with
            commercial credit. Vehicle maintenance should be taken
            seriously. If the government wishes to intervene to protect
            the most socially vulnerable groups, or compensate for
            externalities of traffic congestion and air pollution, it
            should explore what it can do to help the bus companies
            strengthen their finances. Encourage local capacity for
            long-term sustainability. Minimize turnover of the task
            manager and the project manager throughout the project.
